column1: Macroamylasemia is the presence of an abnormal substance called macroamylase in the blood.
Macroamylase is a substance that consists of an enzyme, called amylase, attached to a protein.
Because it is large, macroamylase is filtered very slowly from the blood by the kidneys.

Most people with macroamylasemia do not have a serious disease that is causing it, but the condition has been associated with: - Celiac disease - Lymphoma - HIV infection - Monoclonal gammopathy - Rheumatoid arthritis - Ulcerative colitis
However, macroamylasemia can look similar to acute pancreatitis, which also causes high levels of amylase in the blood.
